body: I would merge #251 with the "fair-use" reasoning and close this.

I agree with @matthiasblaesing that we should merge #251 as soon as possible.  However, looking back through the dev list, our mentors advised us in April to put in a legal ticket to clarify acceptable trademark "fair-use".  Maybe the legal ticket linked above needs bumping and better wording before merging 251, in which case this PR is probably the right stopgap if we can't get an answer quickly.

Trademark fair-use doesn't cover copyright of the artwork, but I assume as they were in NetBeans before we can use under CDDL?
`Group.allGroups()` is a sorted Set right?  So not random but first match?  Which sounds like OK behaviour.
On hold for now.

I notice your tests use: 

```
-XX:+UseCompressedClassPointers 
-XX:+UseCompressedOops 
-XX:-UseLargePagesIndividualAllocation 
-XX:+UseParallelGC  
```

Why?  Does your test results depend on this?

One more thing:  If `Files.newInputStream()` (with try-with-resources of course) is really that much preferable to ` new FileInputStream()` then the IDE should have a hint for it.  Right?

Must admit this whole thing is news to me.  I can see that [Stephen Conollly's blog post](https://www.cloudbees.com/blog/fileinputstream-fileoutputstream-considered-harmful) has gone viral and triggered many projects to review their usage of `FileInputStream` (or `FileOutputStream`). His article was later [published on DZone](https://dzone.com/articles/fileinputstream-fileoutputstream-considered-harmful) were it triggered a minor discussion where Kirk Pepperdine also commented. I don't see Mr Pepperdine disputing that a finalizer causes GC but he seems to argue that it can hardly have that much of an impact. Anyway, that's why it will be interesting to see if there's any real impact on a large code base like NetBeans.

Bottom line: I think we should see some more test results before we begin changing every occurrence of `FileInputStream`. 

Interesting stuff, mdindoffer !
Merging.
This looks great and is critical for the 9.0 Beta release. But what's the problem with the Travis build?
Makes sense to me. Anything to block the merge of this one?
What is the usage for this, i.e., if this is merged, what does one need to do/when/where is something needed to be done to use this?

The problem with the build were connection problems. In the failing logs you saw, that ant tried to download binaries from hg.netbeans.org. Somewhere on the way between travisci and oracle the connection failed.

I restarted the build and today it works through.

it generate an exlusion list based on git. 
This list of excluded file  is added to the "normal" ant rat task with no interference with the human made list.
Nothing to be done to make it work (except having git)

Having git on the PATH sounds like a dangerous assumption. We had a similar problem for patching. Linux users normally have patch on the path, so the author did not recognice, that this could be a problem. At the end we replaced the patch binary with a java solution, it would not be good to regress here.

> `Group.allGroups()` is a sorted Set right?

Yes, a `TreeSet`.

@emilianbold Done manually. Sure there may be a place for a java hint in the future, but this was partly an experiment.  Also, the code is kinda fragile and tangled up in some places, so I prefer to do this stuff manually.

The idea was to apply this change throughout the whole repo in one go, but it proved to be more time consuming than I thought. Yes, the speedup that seems to be present at the boot probably originates from the core. And maybe autoupdate too? If it checks for updates at startup, not entirely sure. However, the point is, if there's a benefit observable in one use case (boot), it should manifest itself in other use cases too, even if negligibly. I also planned to tackle code that touches file searching & replacing and benchmark that. I think the api.search* module (which I plowed through) houses most of the relevant code for this, but not all. However I am not that much familiar with the NB cluster structure to say that for sure.
"but don't like so much" - so, are you against this FI/OS change in general?

@lbruun 
I did not touch the JVM / GC params apart from the Xmx and gc logging. The XXs you list are defaults for x64 Java 8.
The IDE hint seems like a good idea. But as you mentioned, the real life effect can be negligible for most of the use cases nowadays.
I will address the comments and then run some more tests.
BTW [this post](https://arnaudroger.github.io/blog/2017/03/20/faster-reader-inpustream-in-java.html) also provides some nice graphs

>"but don't like so much" - so, are you against this FI/OS change in general?

try-with-resources seems a clear gain because it removes so many finally blocks that just close the stream.

`Files.newInputStream` just looks more ugly with the extra path creation, StandardOpenOption flags, etc.

AFAIK FileInputStream is not outright deprecated and I'm curious if there's really any kind of noticeable impact during normal IDE usage (editing a source file, running the project, etc).

For startup having the most efficient code is important so it would be interesting to narrow down the core modules that need this upgrade.

Basically I would slice-and-dice this into more commits / PRs and even have places where the old code is left alone (because I'm not convinced it has a noticeable effect and there's really no urgent need to switch to the new API and abandon FileInputStream forever).

RatReportTask is build using the same assumption of having the version control tool available with "no issue so far". Mercurial related task were done this way in nbbuild ant task.  

IMHO, the change to a java based version control stuff need to be done for all task in one  go.
+1 Very nice.
Nice, thanks, merging.

Looks OK to me too. We could save the form.binding module (it is an eager module, so it would automatically be enabled when its dependencies are satistied, i.e. if the user installed the beansbinding module), but we can do that later. (And removing it as a dependency of form.kit seems good to me anyways - it does not make much sense to me to include eager modules as dependencies of "kits".

Can you make a little example or do you have a documentation for this? Because I created a plugin called NbScratchFile and I use javaFX webview w/o any Html4J and w/o dukescript, it caused problems on my side, so I created it by my self.
But maybe your approach is better and give some advantages and maybe a better performance?

https://github.com/Chris2011/NbScratchFile/blob/develop/src/main/resources/org/chrisle/netbeans/plugins/utils/WebViewDialog.java

Let us talk separately, which channel do you prefer?

Documentation of these annotations for version 8.2 is [available here](http://bits.netbeans.org/8.2/javadoc/org-netbeans-api-htmlui/overview-summary.html). There are even wizards in the IDE that generate the HTML based UI (component, dialog, as well as wizard for your file types). In general I believe in shared infrastructure rather than doing the same thing again and again from scratch. When people learn how to join forces they usually achieve more than on their own.

Sure me too, but as I said, I had some problems while using dukescript and there is no issue tracker to let them know it. Anyway, thx for the info, I will try to refactor my code to use the HtmlUI üëç. But for me as a FrontEnd WebDeveloper, you can see it in my code, what my use case is. No mixed JS/Java code. Clean HtmlUI with own build process and JS/TS, decoupled from the other logic. Sry for spamming into this PR. I'm finished now :')
There's no bug tracker? And who is 'them'? @JaroslavTulach is one of the key developers of DukeScript, which is part of Apache NetBeans -- i.e., https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans-html4j

I mean a bugtracker for DukeScript, there is no bugtracker and if you mean, that I can use incubator-netbeans-html4j as bugtracking for DukeScript then ok, but this was no obvious. And first you have to activate the issue tracker on the repo so yeah I can't still create issues there.

In my opinion, I thought that DukeScript uses HTML4J but that doesn't mean that HTML4J is responsible for DukeScript problems per se. Only if we can figure out yeah that is a problem in HTML4J and not DukeScript then I should create a ticket there, otherwise I tried to find a bugtracker for DukeScript.

As I understand DukeScript based on HTML4J but it is NOT HTML4J or is NOT part of HTML4J. It is a whole different compoent. Please let me know when I'm wrong. I talked to Anton Epple, because he is the person, that I figured out is responsible for DukeScript, becaue of this page: https://dukescript.com/index.html#contact. No mentioning of Jaruslav etc. But this was not the case what I was asking for.

Let us discuss it in another thread for this, you can see my use case and you can see that the annotations will not fit in my case, because I don't want to write Java as much as I can. But if there is a better choice for me to use HTML4J, better than my implementation, then I will, but then I need help from the guys.

Hi, DukeScript is based on html/java APIs. html/java is part of Apache NetBeans. When we were talking about your plugin, you were using plain html/Java. When using html/Java inside NetBeans, NetBeans issue tracker is the place to report issues. DukeScript.com uses html/Java independent of NetBeans and builds additional Presenters for iOS, Android, and more platforms.

But I admit that we're using this name "DukeScript" rather sloppily, because we're also the creators of the plugin which can be used for both plain html/Java and DukeScript Add-on Presenters so I understand the confusion. 

Toni (Anton Epple)
You can have the honor of closing this one: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-172

> We could save the form.binding module (it is an eager module, so it would automatically be enabled when its dependencies are satistied, i.e. if the user installed the beansbinding module), but we can do that later

@jlahoda: I like this idea very much! I didn't notice that form.binding is eager.

So, for future reference: if we could make o.jdesktop.beansbinding only a compile-time dependency we could still ship form.binding and users would need to install externally just o.jdesktop.beansbinding. (Maybe even go the semi-automated install like we did for JUnit before.)

I'm not pursuing this further but I though it's important to underline how nice this approach would be.
Great, thanks, merging.
+1 Looks good to me. Does anyone have any comments?
Aside from the conflicting files, this looks good, will merge when conflicts are fixed.
Looks good. Can we merge this and open a new issue or do a new pull request for any connected items that need to be worked on?

I feel this closes NETBEANS-144. 

I'll open ticket(s) for the outstanding issues but I don't think they are important for releasing under ASF.
Does Apache require us to show the license acceptance window? I expect the answer is no. Then, the easiest thing is to remove the license acceptance window altogether.

@jtulach. Agreed. But this PR is a stop-gap which allows us to release now. It doesn't exclude other measures in the near future, but it means we don't have to wait for an answer from whoever.

Btw: If active license acceptance by the user is no longer required then we should also remove the equivalent feature from the IDE's installer, not just from ZIP bundle. (however, the IDE's Installer is not yet donated so we cannot make such a change yet, even if we wanted to)

I've updated the PR so that the "outstanding issues" mentioned originally is now also fixed (despite me saying it was difficult to fix, graphically .. it wasn't !). 
Please merge.

I pushed an updated changeset. Change from the first:
- the license header for the WADL xsds was extended to hold a clarification, that for redistribution the CDDL is choosen. This should enable us to redistribute the XSDs unter the https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-b - last paragraph.
- the build failure was fixed. the eclipselink library definition covered more classes, than the replacement from maven central. The further necessary jars were added.

Looks ok, feel free to merge. Just out of curiosity - is the name change needed?
From my point of view, makes sense, and am merging.
Well, one or two mentions of Apache in NetBeans itself would be good. Merging.

Whether it is required or not:

http://apache.org/foundation/marks/pmcs.html#naming:

As you can see the ASF really want us to use "Apache NetBeans" rather than just "NetBeans". If it is strictly required in the locations I've changed in this PR is open for interpretation. But the intent from the ASF is certainly clear. In any case I think it is in our (the (new) NetBeans community) interest too, i.e. to set the product apart from pre-Apache era.

I've looked at Tomcat and Cassandra and they are pretty consistent in using the full name, in particular Tomcat will never, ever, refer to itself as solely "Tomcat". This goes for docs, UI and log messages. 

Btw:  With this change, because of the changed `currentVersion` variable, the name which is printed at the top of the messages log will also change:

```text
System Info: 
  Product Version         = Apache NetBeans IDE Dev (Build 20171128-unknown-revn)
  ...
```
Thanks for your input!
The change looks save and in the worst case it masks the underlying bug. I'm pulling this in.

To document what is going on:

When you refer to an issue in `apichanges.xml` document, as in:

    <issue number="....."/>

the _number_ attribute can now be either a plain number (as before), e.g.

`<issue number="23455"/>`

in which case it will link to a Bugzilla issue, or if it looks like this:

`<issue number="NETBEANS-243"/>`

it will link to an Apache JIRA issue.

I suggest to close this.

- I ran the 9.0-dev IDE with the IM, but without the patch and could reproduce the problem
- I switched to the fix branch, rebuild and tested again
- The IDE reacted correctly (scrolling was possible after invoking the IME)

Just based on testing this is a +1 from me.

Hi Matthias,

Thanks for the thorough review! You're my hero!

The "Type: compile-time" flag only works if license is "GPL-2-CP" in VerifyLibsAndLicenses.java, shall we update the ant task to include BSD licenses as well?
Antonio, "Type: compile-time" should be supported for all licenses (if not, that's a bug I think). But for GPL-2-CP, both "Type: compile-time" and a "Comment" are required.

The (intent of the) current checks is that "Type: compile-time" is required for GPL-2-CP (aongside with a "Comment"). Because we are not allowed to have a hard dependency on GPL code. It is OK to have a hard dependency on BSD, but it is also OK to have a "Type: compile-time" BSD dependency.

Then I think VerifyLibsAndLicenses is perfect.
We then have to decide if the "non nuclear" clause in javacc license is aceptable or not. If not we can upgrade the version, I think.

One thing that is missing is, that the license text matches the text in `nbbuild/licenses/*`. I suggest to: add a license template `nbbuild/licenses/BSD-javacc` with the license body of `db.sql.visualeditor/external/javacc-3.2-license.txt`. And update the `javacc-3.2-license.txt` file to a license named `BSD-javacc` (the performance module also depends on javacc and should be updated accordingly).

I found this by running:
```
ant verify-all-libs-and-licenses
```

Thanks, Matthias.
I've upgraded the "performance" module that also uses javacc 3.2 to reuse this license. One line less in the verifylibsandlicenses file.
Great. I think you should merge this.
Thanks, Steffen! I mispelled a regex, I think.
Looks good, thanks, and merging.
Great, thanks.

D'oh. I deleted this branch by accident. Sorry. Restored it now.
I think we should keep this closed until we decide where to host binaries. Maven central seems to be working fine.
Great. But there seems to be a Travis problem.

I'd like to know if:
a) I'm computing correctly the modules that conform the build.
b) If I'm hooking at appropriate places in "build.xml" for generating the NOTICE file.

Note that as the Apache requirements mandate only the binaries that form part of the build must be included in the final NOTICE file (so, for instance, platform builds will have a NOTICE file different to an ide build).

First: Thank you for looking into this!

Jan did some work on this - see here:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commits/generate-license-notice-dependencies

The branch is far behind master, but it might be good to have a look.

For the added notice files, I think in many cases they need to be smaller:

http://www.apache.org/dev/licensing-howto.html#alv2-dep

> If the dependency supplies a NOTICE file, its contents must be analyzed and the relevant portions bubbled up into the top-level NOTICE file.

And

http://www.apache.org/dev/licensing-howto.html#bundle-asf-product

> It is not necessary to duplicate the line "This product includes software developed at the Apache Software Foundation...", though the ASF copyright line and any other portions of NOTICE must be considered for propagation.

So the "This product includes software developed by The Apache Software Foundation (http://www.apache.org/)." should be removed from the additional notices.

Hi Matthias.

Thank _you_ for looking into this too. This is one of those boring tasks that should be done to move forward.

Yep, I took a look at Jan's branch but we were repeating notice files and AFAIK the notices were all the same for all builds. Note that this PR is about the NOTICE file only, not about the rest of licensing/dependencies/whatever (that would require another PR).

The expression "its contents must be analyzed and the relevant portions bubbled up into the top-level NOTICE file" in the requirements doesn't make sense to me: I need a clear definition of what "relevant portion" means. From my point of view, and since I'm not a lawyer, all the content is a "relevant portion", otherwise it won't be there. Maybe we want to ask legal what "relevant portion" means.

Finally regarding the "It is not necessary to duplicate the line ..." the "it is not necessary" does not imply per se, that we should remove it.  But as you well point out there's another requirement stating that the NOTICE file should be kept small, so there's a bug in the requirements. The line "It is not necessary to duplicate the line..." should be rephrased to read "It is _mandatory_ to remove the line...".  

I'll modify the ant task later on to remove these lines automatically from the NOTICE files when adding them to the final one (but I think we should keep the original NOTICE files intact, as their authors wrote them).

Thanks again,
Antonio

At patch level, it might be better to define a netbeans_default_tmpdir next to netbeans_default_cachedir above.

I feel conflictual about this fix.

On one side, it's good that NetBeans started respecting the OS cache dir. Long ago it did not and it was annoying on macOS, for example, because the user couldn't decide which data is safe to remove (to recover disk space) and which not. I also assume a lot of useless cache got backed up to Time Machine which is not good.

macOS is pretty OK about setting (and clearing) the temp folder and it's rarely on another partition.

On the other hand I can see how from a configuration or security standpoint it might be good not to have NetBeans leak files into various folders. But it feels like a user-configuration thing. (2GB for a temp folder doesn't seem like much, I'll compare with my machines).

So, speaking of NETBEANS-210 I believe NetBeans should have some better user level message about needing extra disk space (it probably throws some error, no?).

In order to help the (minority, I guess, of) users that are in this situation the script could use netbeans_default_tmpdir but initialize it by default with $TMPDIR.

Thus, nothing should change for existing users. But users with smaller $TMPDIRs would just tweak netbeans_default_tmpdir in the script instead of learning about `java.io.tmpdir` and -J-D

Furthermore, we could even have some UI allowing the user to tweak this folder. Also, add another method to `Places` (http://bits.netbeans.org/8.1/javadoc/org-openide-modules/org/openide/modules/Places.html ) which will be used by modules like the Maven support.

Hi,

(I've edited the title to see if this sends stuff to JIRA).

Good points, Emilian, thanks.

Maybe the problem is with the Maven indexer itself. Instead of trying to fill the java.io.tmpdir until exhaustion and then fail (for those systems where java.io.tmpdir lives in memory this is very bad) it should probably check first if there's enough space to proceed.

Since that's tough to do in a portable way maybe the best workaround is to have the maven indexer to use Places to create a  specific working directory in the "cache directory" and ensure that it's cleaned up once it's done. 

On startup we could check if that working directory exists (because of previous fatal exit, for instance) and clean it up too.

The "tmp" partition space is the default Debian installation size, so I assume many Debian users will suffer the problem. I may want to see if Debian derivatives are also affected. Will report back.
Making `javac` optional is an essential step. Let's do it.
